Introduction

This policy has been developed in line with local and national guidance to provide support to staff on the implementation and adherence to the Mental Capacity Act of 2005. A complete version of the Mental Capacity Act 2005 can be found by using the following link: http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2005/9/contents

This policy is aimed at all staff working for Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust who come into contact with patients / individuals over the age of 16 years. The aim of this policy is to assist staff in identifying patients / individuals who may lack mental capacity to make certain decisions that affect them, and how staff can support individuals in their best interest, including decisions regarding treatment and care. It is therefore important that staff have a working understanding of how and when to apply the Mental Capacity Act 2005 during the care and treatment of patients / individuals in the care of Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust. This policy now includes decisions relating to young people under 16 years (also to be found in the SET Safeguarding Children Procedures) and also some guidance to critical care services.
The Mental Capacity Act (2005) applies to individuals aged 16 and over and sets out 5 principles that should be adhered to and evidenced when supporting patients / individuals:
A person (aged 16 and over) must be assumed to have capacity unless it is established that he / she lacks capacity
A person is not to be treated as unable to make a decision unless all practicable steps to help him / her to do so have been taken without success.
A person is not to be treated as unable to make a decision merely because he / she makes an unwise decision.
An act done, or decision made, under this act for or on behalf of a person who lacks capacity must be done, or made, in his best interests.

Before the act is done, or the decision is made, regard must be had to whether the purpose for which it is needed can be effectively achieved in a way that is less restrictive of the person's rights and freedom of action.
SET Mental Capacity Act and Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards Policy and Guidance (March 2018).
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

Outline the Trust policy to follow the principles of the Mental Capacity Act 2005 which provides a legal framework for acting and making decisions on behalf of individuals who lack capacity to make particular decisions for themselves.

Ensure everyone working with or caring for an adult (or adolescent over the age of 16) who may lack capacity to make decisions, works in compliance with the Mental Capacity Act (MCA) when acting for that person, ensuring this is reflected in the patient's clinical records to provide evidence that the principles of the Act have been followed in practice.
To provide guidance on how and when to apply the Act and how to document assessments and decisions.
This document must be used in conjunction with the Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice which can be accessed using the following link:
https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attach ment_data/file/497253/Mental-capacity-act-code-of-practice.pdf

Mental Capacity Act 2005 and its application to practice

The Mental Capacity Act 2005 provides the legal framework for acting and making decisions on behalf of individuals who lack the capacity to make specific decisions. Everyone working with or caring for an individual (age 16 or over) who may lack capacity must comply with the Mental Capacity Act 2005 and the Code of Practice (2007)
Principles of the Mental Capacity Act 2005:
The Mental Capacity Act (2005) applies to individuals aged 16 and over and sets out 5 principles that should be adhered to and evidenced when supporting patients / individuals:
A person (aged 16 and over) must be assumed to have capacity unless it is established that he / she lacks capacity
A person is not to be treated as unable to make a decision unless all practicable steps to help him / her to do so have been taken without success.
A person is not to be treated as unable to make a decision merely because he / she makes an unwise decision.
An act done, or decision made, under this act for or on behalf of a person who lacks capacity must be done, or made, in his best interests.

Before the act is done, or the decision is made, regard must be had to whether the purpose for which it is needed can be effectively achieved in a way that is less restrictive of the person's rights and freedom of action.
SET Mental Capacity Act and Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards Policy and Guidance (March 2018).
When is an assessment of mental capacity required and by whom?

All persons aged 16 or over must be presumed to have capacity to make decisions unless proven otherwise. Under the Mental Capacity Act of 2005 (MCA), assessment of mental capacity must only be conducted when there are doubts about an individual's ability to make a specific decision, or consent to a specific action.

The Mental Capacity Act 2005 states that the individual who is going to take action or make a decision on behalf of an adult should be the person who assesses their capacity. The person leading on the individual action is therefore called the decision maker. For example, in the case of change of accommodation, whether temporary or permanent, a Social Worker may be best placed to be the decision maker. Whereas in decisions involving medical treatment or investigations, a clinician would be the decision maker. Further examples can be found in the document SET Mental Capacity Act and Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards Policy and Guidance (March 2018). It is essential that professionals must work together in the best interest of the individual and agree who is best placed to undertake the assessment, in line with available guidance. This process must never delay or be of detriment to an individual's care or treatment.

The assessor does not need to be a qualified individual but should have the necessary skills and knowledge of the Mental Capacity Act and Code of Practice. The decision maker or assessor has to be satisfied that the individual lacks capacity in the decision to be made. The Act offers carers, healthcare and social care staff protection from liability when offering care or treatment, as long as they have a reasonable belief that the person has or does not have capacity. To have a reasonable belief, the assessor must be able to show that they have taken reasonable steps in coming to their conclusion in regards to mental capacity.
Assessment of mental capacity for day to day decisions

During day to day care, an individual needs to validly consent to that care. However, it is recognised that in practice some individuals may lack the mental capacity to make decisions around day to day care, such as consenting to hygiene needs or eating and drinking. It would impact on care to gain consent and assess capacity on every single occasion that assistance is required. Assessments of mental capacity regarding day to day decisions should be carefully recorded but does not require assessment on the Trust approved MCA form, but instead can be recorded in the individuals care plan or case notes.

5.5.1  Simple day to day decisions can be made by the decision maker in the person's best interest if there is a reasonable belief that the individual lacks mental capacity. The decision and action must be reflected by good documentation in the patient's best interests, evidencing how the decision of mental capacity was reached.
Assessment of mental capacity for complex decisions

The Trust approved Mental Capacity Assessment Form (Appendix 1) must be completed by an appropriately and competent professional with appropriate support from specialised colleagues for all complex decisions. Any doubts about who is the most appropriate individual to undertake the assessment must be discussed and advice sought from an MCA Lead. It is therefore important that all staff understand what may be deemed as a complex decision and when a mental capacity assessment on the approved form (Appendix 1), may be required.
5.6.1 A complex decision may be one where there are serious or long term consequences for the individual such as:
A change of accommodation
Limitations on who the individual can and can't have contact with
Medical treatment which will have long term consequences or may endanger life
Major financial decisions that may involve for example, mortgages
Entering into or terminating tenancy agreements
Consent to sexual relations (Specific legal test applies, refer to current case law)
SET Mental Capacity Act and Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards Policy and Guidance (March 2018).
5.6.2 The above list is not exhaustive. MSE leads would also suggest the following should be considered as complex decisions:
Refusal of care or treatment
An aspect of care or treatment that could have a potential negative impact on the individual if not undertaken
End of life care / treatment
Potential withdrawal of treatment
5.6.3 An understanding of an individual's mental capacity should be seen as an essential to patient centred care and a tool that can be used to promote best practice for the individual.

5.6.4 The Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust currently uses the 2 part Mental Capacity Assessment (refer to appendix 1) and it is an expectation that its staff must use this form for any complex decision where it is believed an individual may lack mental capacity.

5.6.5 It is not a requirement by law for a mental capacity assessment to be undertaken by more than one professional. However, staff should consider the benefits or appropriateness of more than one assessor on a case by case basis. Examples of situations when more than one assessor may be beneficial:
Where significant restraint is required
Where there is a known conflict about the care and support of the individual
Where it is likely that the adults family may dispute or complain about the outcome of the mental capacity assessment
Where capacity is fluctuating or is difficult to assess
Where a known co-dependent relationship is involved which has been a source of conflict or risk.
SET Mental Capacity Act and Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards Policy and Guidance (March 2018).
When an assessment of mental capacity should be undertaken.

‘A person lacks mental capacity in relation to a matter, if at the material time, he / she is unable to make a decision for him/herself in relation to the matter because of an impairment of, or disturbance in the functioning of the mind or brain'.
MCA 2005 Code of Practice

5.7.1 If required a mental capacity assessment (Appendix 1) should be undertaken to assess a person's ability to make a specific decision at the time that the decision is required and must be decided on the balance of probabilities. All MCA assessments should be filed in the patient's notes and sent to the Site Safeguarding Team using the following email address:
shn-tr.msb.dolsmca@nhs.net

5.7.2 If there is evidence to show that the person's capacity is likely to improve, then it should be considered whether complex decisions should be delayed if possible (and reasonably) until such time when the individual may be able to make the decision themselves. All assessments of capacity must be decision and time specific, and monitoring and review of the decision should also be considered as individuals may regain capacity. In some situations more than one capacity assessment may be required. For example, the assessment for capacity on deeming an individual medically fit for discharge - A person may have the capacity to be involved in medically fit for discharge decisions, but a mental capacity assessment and decision on long term social care may also be required.

5.7.3 In the persons best interest, when the decision maker confirms a decision, they must take into account the views of any involved family or friends, or any advance decisions made by the person. Any decision made should be the least restrictive option.

5.7.4 Good documentation is essential. Documenting that there is no reason to question capacity and therefore an assessment is not required can be as important as assessing and documenting that an individual does not have capacity. How a decision has been reached should always be explicit within the documentation. If

there is any doubt as to an individual's mental capacity or if there are disagreements as to the individuals capacity, then a full mental capacity assessment using the agreed Trust tool (Appendix 1) should be completed.
Urgent decisions

For urgent decisions on care, the decision maker can make a decision as long as it is in the person's best interest, and there is clear documentation made. To have a reasonable belief, the staff member must be able to show that they have taken reasonable and proportionate steps in coming to their conclusion. If the decision is non-urgent then delaying the decision should be considered until a best interest process can be undertaken.
Situational incapacity

All staff must be aware of and be vigilant to the difference between lack of mental capacity as a result of an impairment / disturbance in mind / brain, and a situation where a person is unable to make their own decision as a result of duress or undue influence. There are situations when an individual that has mental capacity but their ability to give free and true consent is impaired if they are under constraint, coercion or undue influence. An individual's decision making may be influenced by an erosion of confidence, fear of reprisal or abandonment, sense of obligation, cultural factors, power relationships or coercive control within domestic abuse.

5.9.1  In such situations, it is possible that stage 1 of the mental capacity assessment (impairment or disturbance in the functioning of the person's mind or brain) would not be met. All staff must evidence that they have taken reasonable measures to support individuals to make decisions freely by creating a supportive and conducive environment when the individual can feel safe and supported to make decisions. In some situations when there is evidence of situational incapacity as a result of coercion or influence, then legal advice may be necessary and a safeguarding referral may be required.
Refusal to engage in the mental capacity assessment

There are situations when an individual may refuse to engage in an assessment of mental capacity for a specific decision. Staff are expected to make reasonable efforts to gain a rapport with the individual and provide the necessary information for the person to understand the consequences of not making the required decision. The individual must be advised that if they decline to engage, then the relevant professional will need to make a determination of the individuals ability to make this specific decision on the balance of probabilities; taking into account the knowledge they already have about the individual, their cognitive abilities, diagnosis and presentation. Also refer to the guidance on situational incapacity (5.9).

5.10.1 It may be clear that the refusal to engage is because of a lack of understanding of the process due to impairment or disturbance of the mind or brain. In this situation, it may be concluded that on the balance of probabilities the individual lacks mental capacity to agree or refuse the assessment, and the mental capacity assessment should continue (although no one can be forced to undertake an assessment of mental capacity).
Decisions excluded by the Mental Capacity Act 2005:
Consenting to marriage or a civil partnership
Consenting to have sexual relations
Consenting to a decree of divorce on the basis of two years separation
consenting to the dissolution of a civil partnership
Consenting to a child being placed for adoption or the making of an adoption or the making of an adoption order
Discharging parental responsibility for a child in matters not relating to the child's property, or
Giving consent under the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act 1990
Mental Capacity Act and Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards Policy and Guidance SET 2018
Power of Attorney or a Court Appointed Deputy

A lasting power of attorney (LPA) is a legal document that lets the individual (the ‘donor') appoint one or more people (known as ‘attorneys') to help them make decisions or to make decisions on their behalf. To make an LPA, the individual must be 18 or over and have mental capacity (the ability to make your own decisions) at the time of making the LPA. There are 2 types of LPA:
Health and welfare
Property and financial affairs
Health and Welfare Lasting Power of Attorney
Health and Welfare Lasting Power of Attorney can be used to give an agreed attorney the power to make decisions about things such as:
Daily routine, for example washing, dressing, eating
Medical care
Moving into a care home

Life-sustaining treatment (must be expressly documented within the Lasting Power of Attorney whether an individual has given the attorney the authority to make life sustaining treatment decisions on the individuals behalf)
5.13.1 A Health and Welfare LPA can only be used when an individual is unable to make their own decisions / lacks capacity to make health and welfare decisions.
Property and Financial Affairs Lasting Power of Attorney
Property and Financial Affairs Lasting Power of Attorney can be used to give an attorney the power to make decisions about money and property for an individual. For example:
Managing a bank or building society account
Paying bills
Collecting benefits or a pension
Selling your home
5.14.1 An LPA for Property and Affairs can be used as soon as it's registered, with an individual's permission.
5.14.2 For further information about Power of Attorney, refer to: www.gov.uk/government/organisations/office-of-the-public-guardian/about
Court Appointed Deputy
As a deputy, an individual is authorised by the Court of Protection to make decisions on someone's behalf. There are 2 types of deputy.
Property and Financial Affairs Deputy – can do things like pay the person's bills or organise their pension.
Personal Welfare Deputy – can make decisions about medical treatment and how someone is looked after.
5.17.1 The court will usually only appoint a personal welfare deputy if:
There's doubt whether decisions will be made in someone's best interest for example because the family disagree about care
Someone needs to be appointed to make decisions about a specific issue over time, for example where someone will live.
Action to take if an individual states they are a donee of LPA or Deputy

If an individual states that they are a donee of LPA or Deputy, personal welfare and / or property and affairs, then the decision maker must assure themselves of the validity of such statements by requesting to see supporting paperwork issued by the Office of the Public Guardian and making reasonable checks that the LPA is valid, registered and covers the decisions required.
5.18.1 To find out if someone has an Attorney, Deputy or Guardian acting for them then the Office of the Public Guardian should be contacted:
Find out if someone has an attorney, deputy or guardian acting for them - GOV.UK (www.gov.uk)

5.18.2 If it is concluded that an individual lacks the capacity to a make a decision and they have a donee of LPA or Deputy, then unless there are safeguarding concerns, the decision maker is the donee of LPA or Deputy.

5.18.3 If there are concerns that a donee of LPA or the Deputy is not acting in the best interest of the individual, then a safeguarding concern must be raised and the Office of the Public Guardian notified.
Determining a person's best interests

Under the guidance of the Mental Capacity Act, any decisions made by the decision maker must be made in the persons best interests. This must take into account all relevant circumstances of their medical, emotional and social issues. All assessments, and decisions must be documented in the patient record, and include a relevant Mental Capacity Act Assessment Form (complex decisions). All members of the relevant multi-disciplinary team must be involved in the best interest process process.

5.19.1 It is important that the lead decision maker can evidence the best interest process that was followed to reach the decision using the best interest decision tool within the Trust Mental Capacity Assessment Tool (Appendix 1).
5.19.2 The following points must also be considered:
Decide whether the decision can be delayed until the person regains capacity to make the decision for themselves
All relevant circumstances, including a person's beliefs, values, past and present wishes, and other factors that would be likely to influence them if they had capacity.
Any written statements the person made when they had capacity, such as an Advance Decision Document or Lasting Power of Attorney Document.
All efforts must be made / reasonable adjustments considered, to enable the person to be involved in the decision making process for example involving an interpreter or using communication aids
Other factors which might have influenced the person's decision such as altruistic motives, consideration for others and duties and obligations towards future beneficiaries and/or dependents
The views of other people who may be able to advice on what would be in the person's best interests
In the case of medical treatment, there should be no motivation or desire to bring about the person's death when the decision relates to life-sustaining treatment

Whether any action required can be achieved in a less restrictive or invasive manner. Where there are no relatives or friends to liaise with, an Independent Mental Capacity Advocate (IMCA) must be involved to provide a view on the individual's behalf, if the individual has been deemed as not having capacity.
Referral to an Independent Mental Capacity Advocate (IMCA)

In most situations people who lack capacity will have a network of support from family members or friends (who take an interest in their welfare) or from a Lasting Power of Attorney. However, some people who lack capacity may have no one to support them (other than paid staff) with complex decisions. The Mental Capacity Act 2005 created an Independent Mental Capacity Advocate (IMCA) service. Its purpose is to help individuals who lack mental capacity to contribute to important decisions by the NHS and Local Authorities on the individuals behalf.

5.20.1 It is a statutory duty to appoint an IMCA where it is determined that an adult lacks mental capacity and has nobody to support them other than paid staff and a specific decision is being made about one the following:
A Change of accommodation
A move to a care home for more than 8 weeks or an admission to a hospital bed for 28 days or more
Serious medical treatment (including DNAR decisions)
A Deprivation of Liberty Safeguard has been applied for the person to help keep then safe
Care reviews (where no-one else is available to be consulted
Adult safeguarding cases – whether or not family, friend or others are involved.

5.20.2 Where a person has no family or friends involved with their care and treatment, or where the family or friends do not appear to be working within the patient's best interest, then the decision maker must involve an Independent Mental Capacity Advocate (IMCA).
5.20.3 NB: An IMCA is not required if treatment is to be given under the Mental Health Act (1983) for a mental health disorder, as the Mental Health Act of 1983 overrides the Mental Capacity Act.
5.20.4 An IMCA is not the decision maker, but the decision-maker will have a duty to take into account the information, views and opinions given by the IMCA on the individual's behalf.

5.20.5 Any referrals to the IMCA service should be discussed with the Site Safeguarding Adults Teams where possible in the first instance. Staff can however, refer directly to the appropriate IMCA provider:
South Essex Advocacy Services (Southend Site):
Advocacy Hub – Supporting Southend-on-Sea (sosadvocacyhub.org)
Rethink (Basildon and Broomfield Sites):
Rethink Advocacy | Make a referral (rethinkessexadvocacy.org)

Services / referrers are advised to also verbally speak to the IMCA provider by phone, before submitting a referral, or directly after. This will help to ensure the IMCA provider is aware of, and understands any time critical decisions that may be required.
5.20.6 The duties of the IMCA are to:
Support the person who lacks capacity and represent their views and interests to the decision-maker

Obtain and evaluate information – an IMCA can talk to the person in private and examine, and, where appropriate take copies or health & social care records, but only records that are relevant to the issues raised.
Ascertain (as far as possible) the persons values, beliefs, wishes and feelings
Ascertain alternative courses of action
Obtain a further medical opinion if necessary
Prepare a report for the person who instructed them
If an IMCA disagrees with the decision made , they can also challenge the decision-maker
Advance Decisions to Refuse Treatment (ADRT)
The Mental Capacity Act of 2005 allows people over the age of 18 years to make advanced decisions to refuse treatment (ADRT). The following guidance must be considered:

- The responsibility for making an advanced decision and bringing this to the attention of the health professionals involved is the responsibility of the individual making it, at a time when they have the mental capacity to make such a decision.
- An advance decision to refuse treatment is a legally binding document if that advance decision can be shown to be valid and applicable to the current circumstances.
- The ADRT must be signed and witnessed, and state clearly that the decision applies even if life is threatened.
- The ADRT must be valid and applicable to current circumstances.

- Healthcare professionals will be protected from liability if they stop treatment because they reasonably believe an ADRT is valid and applicable. If they provide treatment they must satisfy themselves that a valid ADRT does not exist, or that the person would review the decision in light of new circumstances, for example a new medical treatment has been developed since the ADRT.
- When working within best interests according to chapter 5 of the code of practice, the healthcare professionals must seek any expression of previous wishes.

- Healthcare professionals do not have to work against their own personal beliefs but must not abandon patients or act in a way that affects their care. If the decision is one of conscience, arrangements must be made to transfer the care to another professional.
- These rules may not apply for someone under the Mental health Act.
- People must not be coerced into writing ADRT.
- ADRT have the same legal status as a person with capacity making a decision at the time it is needed.
- Healthcare professionals must assess that an ADRT is applicable to the circumstances that exist at the time of the decision.
- An ADRT does not apply to other decisions on care, for example, place of care.
- If there are grounds for reasonable doubt about issues on ADRT, the professional may provide treatment to sustain life if it is considered as part of a best interests decision.
- The ADRT must clearly state what treatment the person wishes to refuse, for example they may refuse to have antibiotics for a chest infection but not for a urinary tract infection.
- There is no set format for an ADRT, however a proforma is available in this document, and also on the hospital intranet. Example templates:
Advance Decisions (Living Wills) | Compassion in Dying
- Witnessing an advanced decision will confirm that it is the persons signature and the wishes of the person are clearly set out in the ADRT. The witness is not assessing capacity.
- Where possible a professional must record a verbal ADRT in the person's health record, and document a witness, and the capacity in which the witness was present.
- An ADRT cannot refuse basic comfort measures such as warmth shelter and basic care, as section 5 of the act allows professionals to undertake these under the person's best interests.
- An ADRT can refuse artificial nutrition, including enteral feeding, subcutaneous and intravenous nutrition.
5.21.1 A valid ADRT will overrule any lasting power of attorney that was made before the ADRT was drawn up. So an attorney cannot give consent to treatment that has since been declared under an ADRT.
5.21.2 The Court of Protection may make declarations as to the validity of an ADRT, and can advise on cases on disagreement over an ADRT, but has no power to overrule a valid ADRT.
Advanced decisions made prior to October 2007.

If an ADRT was made before the Mental Capacity Act came into force, professionals should advise individuals to review the ADRT and date the decision to ensure they meet the requirements of the mental capacity act.
Advance statements

An advance statement is a written statement by an individual to specify preferences, wishes, beliefs and values regarding future care. The aim of an advance statement is to provide a guide to anyone who might have to make decisions in the best interest if an individual.
5.23.1 An advance statement can cover any aspect of your health or social care and can include:
How an individual would like their religious or spiritual beliefs met
Where an individual would like to be cared for
How an individual would like their care to be delivered
5.23.2 An advance statement can help to make things clear to family, carers and anybody involved in an individual's care.

5.23.3 An advance statement is different from an advance decision. An advance decision refers to treatment and is legally binding (as long as it meets necessary criteria). An advance statement refers to care delivery and is not legally binding but it is good practice to consider the advance statement in the care planning of an individual. An advance statement is written when an individual has the capacity to express their care needs / wishes and should state who needs to see it. An advance statement is not used as means to demand specific care or treatment but is a means of expressing preference.
Young people and the Mental Capacity Act

The Mental Capacity Act 2005 states that everyone aged 16 and over is presumed to have mental capacity. The Children's Act 1989 notes that a young person does not legally become an adult until their 18th birthday. Section 8 of the Family Law Reform Act 1969 provides that young people age 16 and 17 have the right to consent to treatment and that such treatment can be given without the need to obtain consent of a person with parental responsibility.

5.1.1 When a young person aged 16 or over has mental capacity and does not consent to a decision, their wishes and views must be upheld. Professionals are advised against relying on the consent of a person with parental responsibility and are advised to seek legal advice if required.

5.1.2 Where a person aged 16 or over lacks mental capacity to make a specific decision, the decision should be taken within the framework of the mental Capacity Act 2005 and the guidance within this policy and documents to which it refers.

5.1.3 Young people under the age of 16 may still have mental capacity or be Gillick– competent to make a decision. For a young person under the age of 16, the professional has a duty to evidence that the young person has mental capacity or is Gillick-competent. The law presumes that a young person aged 16 or over has mental capacity to make all decisions.
5.1.4 There is no set of defined questions to assess Gillick competency. Professionals need to consider several things when assessing a child's capacity to consent, including:
The child's age, maturity and mental capacity
Their understanding of the issue and what it involves - including advantages, disadvantages and potential long-term impact
Their understanding of the risks, implications and consequences that may arise from their decision
How well they understand any advice or information they have been given
Their understanding of any alternative options, if available
Their ability to explain a rationale around their reasoning and decision making.
Remember that consent is not valid if a young person is being pressured or influenced by someone else.

5.1.5 A child's capacity to consent may be affected by different factors, for example stress, mental health conditions and the complexities of the decision they are making. The same child may be considered Gillick competent to make one decision but not competent to make a different decision.
5.1.6 If an individual does not believe a child is Gillick competent or there are inconsistencies in their understanding, the individual should seek consent from parents or carers before proceeding.
Mental capacity in critical care settings

Every effort must be made to establish whether a person has the capacity to make a decision or not. In the critical care setting it may be clear that a person lacks capacity to make a decision. Even where a lack of capacity is obvious, this fact should be recorded and the clinicians should accept that, at that time, they are bound to act in the best interests of the patient. In circumstances where the issue of capacity is not clear, an assessment of capacity must be undertaken and documented, even if the conclusion is that capacity is absent.

5.2.1 Some patients will still have the capacity to make decisions within critical care settings or when they are receiving high dependency care. It is essential that all reasonable efforts are made to involve such individuals in both present and anticipated future decision making, and where an assessment shows that lack of capacity makes this impossible, the process of reaching this conclusion needs to be clinically documented.

5.2.2 Mental capacity assessment and best interest decision processes can potentially involve a delay in decision making, and such delays may not always be in the patient's best interests or be clinically acceptable in the setting of critical illness, where urgent intervention may be required. If decisions need to be made in the interim, the lead clinician, as the person is charged with making the decision on behalf of the patient.
5.2.3 A judgment needs to be made as to the extent to which it is important to take immediate decisions to protect the patient and promote his best interests.

5.2.4 However where a matter is important and urgent and requires referral to the Court of Protection, a court hearing can be set up in a matter of hours with a telephone hearing for the Judge to reach a decision.

5.2.5 Where a matter is serious and the clinician feels that interim action is required despite the objections of the family, the clinician can proceed with interventions, providing that it can be demonstrated that the principles outlined in the mental Capacity Act 2005 were followed, and there were reasonable grounds for believing that the action was in the patient's best interests. The interim action in such circumstances should be the minimal needed to protect the patient's best interests whilst any dispute is resolved. In an emergency this can, in some circumstances, mean carrying out major medical interventions despite opposition from members of the patient's family. However this should be avoided wherever it is possible to do so.

5.2.6 For further guidance on the practical application of MCA and best interest within critical care settings then refer to Mental Capacity Act 2005: Guidance for Critical Care (Intensive Care Society 2011.
5.2.7 An MCA / Best Interest Tool for critical care environments can be found in Appendix 2.
Training Requirements

All staff with direct patient contact must attend Adult Safeguarding / MCA training every 3 years. The training will be monitored through i-learn and Directorate Leads are responsible for ensuring their staff attend in line with Trust procedures. Each department must ensure that 95% of staff mapped to this training, are compliant.

What are you proposing to change?
This is a review of an existing guideline that now reflects the new MSE Structure and unification of practice across all 3 sites.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)

To ensure appropriate guidelines are in place to support staff at a service level and to ensure best interest decisions are undertaken within statutory requirements. To ensure the guidance is applicable to all appropriate services within the MSE Group.
Who benefits from this change and how?

All individuals over the age of 16 where day to day or complex decisions are required. Staff – To support staff at a service level and to ensure best interest decisions are undertaken within statutory requirements.

No – The policy is clear as to which patient groups / individuals this policy applies to.
